Percent green space along walkable roads
layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates green space along walkable roads. Green space within 25 meters of the road centerline is included and the percentage is based on the total area between street intersections. Green space provides valuable benefits to neighborhood residents and walkers by providing shade, improved aesthetics, and outdoor gathering spaces.

layer.eaDescription: This EnviroAtlas dataset estimates tree cover along walkable roads. The road width is estimated for each road and percent tree cover is calculated in a 8.5 meter strip beginning at the estimated road edge. Percent tree cover is calculated for each block between road intersections. Tree cover provides valuable benefits to neighborhood residents and walkers by providing shade, improved aesthetics, and outdoor gathering spaces.

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the acres of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that are enrolled in the US Department of Agriculture's Conservation Reserve Program (CRP). Category III protected areas are set aside to protect a specific natural monument, which can be a landform, sea mount, submarine cavern, geological feature such as a cave or even a living feature such as an ancient grove. They are generally quite small protected areas and often have high visitor value.

layer.eaDescription: This map portrays the percentage of land within each subwatershed (12-digit HUC) that has been classified as Status IV by International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) for 2011. Category IV areas aim to protect particular species or habitats and management reflects this priority. Many Category IV protected areas will need regular, active interventions to address the requirements of particular species or to maintain habitats, but this is not a requirement of the category.

layer.eaDescription: The EnviroAtlas Potential Wetland Areas (PWA) dataset shows potential wetland areas at 30-meter resolution. Beginning two centuries ago, many wetlands were turned into farm fields or urban areas, yet wetlands play an important role in removing water pollution, regulating water storage and flows, and providing habitat for wildlife. Wetland restoration could help restore these benefits. Potential wetland areas, as developed for this map, are lands that naturally accumulate water due to topography and have historically had poorly or very poorly draining soils. This dataset was produced by the US EPA to support research and online mapping activities related to the EnviroAtlas. EnviroAtlas (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas) allows the user to interact with a web-based, easy-to-use, mapping application to view and analyze multiple ecosystem services for the contiguous United States. The dataset is available as downloadable data (https://edg.epa.gov/data/Public/ORD/EnviroAtlas) or as an EnviroAtlas map service. Additional descriptive information about each attribute in this dataset can be found in its associated EnviroAtlas Fact Sheet (https://www.epa.gov/enviroatlas/enviroatlas-fact-sheets).

layer.name: National Land Cover (NLCD) NLCD_2011
layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2011 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that has been applied consistently across the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters.For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: NLCD_2001
layer.eaDescription: NLCD  (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2001 is a 16-class land cover classification scheme that also has been applied to the conterminous U.S. at a spatial resolution of 30 meters, and includes Alaska, Hawaii, and Puerto Rico. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: NLCD_2006
layer.eaDescription: NLCD (National Land Cover Database) classifications are based primarily on Landsat data along with ancillary data sources, such as topography, census and agricultural statistics, soil characteristics, wetlands, and other land cover maps. NLCD 2006 is a 16-class scheme that quantifies land cover change for the conterminous U.S. between the years 2001 to 2006. Generation of NLCD 2006 helped identify and correct issues in the NLCD 2001 land cover and impervious surface products only and no changes were made to the NLCD 2001 canopy product. For additional information, go to https://www.mrlc.gov/. See https://viewer.nationalmap.gov/help for assistance with The National Map viewer, services, or metadata.

layer.name: Soils Drainage Class - dominant condition
layer.eaDescription: This category contains a map of a variable from the U.S. Natural Resources Conservation Service's soils dataset, called SSURGO (Soil Survey Geographic Database), that contains all variables found in county soil surveys. The SSURGO variable natural drainage class (dominant condition) was selected for use in EnviroAtlas because it indicates soil wetness or degree of saturation.

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which watershed ecosystem service projects operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research.
layer.name: Watershed - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which watershed ecosystem service markets operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Watershed - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent the HUC8 watersheds that primary impact areas of watershed projects correspond with or exist within per Ecosystem Marketplace research. The standard geographic units for depicting watershed projects are HUC8 watersheds. There are no watershed projects identified as being larger than “local” per the above definition at this time
layer.name: Watershed - Projects [boundaries]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent the HUC8 watersheds that market coverage areas of local watershed markets correspond with or exist within per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Watershed markets are identified as local if their market coverage areas encompass two or fewer HUC8 watersheds. The exception to this rule is the Deschutes Groundwater Mitigation Program, whose coverage encompasses greater than two HUC8 watersheds but is considered to be local in this dataset. The standard geographic units for depicting local watershed markets are HUC8 watersheds.
layer.name: Watersheds - Local-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent watershed market coverage areas associated with watershed markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states, counties, and/or a minimum of three HUC8 watersheds according to Ecosystem Marketplace research. Data were derived from disparate sources and merged into a single shapefile. There are no identified regional-level projects at this time.
layer.name: Watersheds - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent watershed market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level watershed projects at this time
layer.name: Watersheds - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with watershed markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national watershed projects at this time.
layer.name: Watersheds - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which imperiled species and/or habitat ecosystem service projects operate. Credit bank point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional imperiled species and/or habitat project point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which imperiled species and/or habitat ecosystem service markets operate per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent project footprints and project primary impact areas associated with imperiled species and/or habitat projects. Credit bank project footprints and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional imperiled species and/or habitat project polygons generated from Ecosystem Marketplace were drawn corresponding with the HUC8 boundaries in which projects operate and merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - Projects [boundaries]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with regional imperiled species and/or habitat markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states or the majority of a state’s geographic area per ecosystem marketplace research. There are no identified local imperiled species and/or habitat markets identified at this time.

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitat - Regional-scale Markets

layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent imperiled species and/or habitat market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level imperiled species and/or habitat projects at this time.

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitat - State-scale Markets

layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with imperiled species and/or habitat markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national imperiled species and/or habitat projects at this time.

fieldInfos.label: Imperiled Species and Habitat - National-scale Markets

layer.name: Imperiled Species and Habitat - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of project footprints or project primary impact areas in which wetland and stream ecosystem service projects operate. Credit bank point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream project point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas in which wetland and stream ecosystem service markets operate. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations. In-lieu fee program point data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream market point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent project footprints and project primary impact areas associated with wetland and stream projects. Credit bank project footprints and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream project polygons generated from Ecosystem Marketplace were drawn corresponding with the HUC8 boundaries in which projects operate and merged with RIBITS data.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Projects [boundaries]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with regional wetland and stream markets operating at a scale encompassing multiple states or the majority of a state’s geographic areas. In-lieu fee program polygon data and corresponding attributes were downloaded from USACE RIBITS website and imported into ArcGIS using the KML-shapefile conversion tool. Additional wetland and stream market point data generated from Ecosystem Marketplace research were merged with RIBITS data. There are no identified local wetland and stream markets identified at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - Regional-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent wetland and stream market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level wetland and stream projects at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent market coverage areas associated with wetland and stream markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national wetland and stream projects at this time.
layer.name: Wetlands and Streams - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the locations of forest carbon ecosystem service projects. Point data were sourced from pre-existing lat/lon coordinates of forest carbon project locations compiled through Ecosystem Marketplace research.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - Projects [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Points represent the centroids of market coverage areas associated with forest carbon markets per Ecosystem Marketplace research. National-level markets are an exception to this norm with points representing administrative headquarters locations.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - Markets [centroids]

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent forest carbon market coverage areas whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified state-level forest carbon projects at this time.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - State-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent forest carbon market coverage areas associated with forest carbon markets operating at a national scale per Ecosystem Marketplace research. There are no identified national forest carbon projects at this time.
layer.name: Forest Carbon - National-scale Markets

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent HUC8 watersheds in which a watershed-level enabling condition is implemented. Watershed-level enabling conditions are those whose boundaries correspond with or exist within two or fewer HUC8 watersheds. The exception to this is the collection of Deschutes Basin Ground Water Mitigation Rules, whose coverage encompasses greater than two HUC8 watersheds but is considered to be local, or watershed-level, in this dataset. Identified watershed-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Watershed-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with state boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified state-level enabling conditions apply for watershed, Imperiled Species and Habitats, wetland and streams, and forest carbon asset types.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - State-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries encompass: a) for imperiled species/habitat, wetland/stream, and forest carbon asset types, at least the majority of a state’s geographic area; b) for watershed asset types, a minimum of three HUC8 watersheds. Identified regional-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Regional-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with federal lands boundaries per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified federal lands-level enabling conditions apply only for watershed and imperiled species/habitat ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - Federal lands-scale

layer.eaDescription: Polygons represent enabling conditions whose boundaries correspond with the U.S. national boundary per Ecosystem Marketplace research. Identified national-level enabling conditions apply for watershed, Imperiled Species and Habitats, and wetland and stream ecosystem service initiatives at this time.
layer.name: Enabling Conditions - National-scale
